sentences.sentence: The geographer was suddenly stirred( 被激起 ) to excitement.
“But you—you come from far away! You are an explorer! You shall describe your planet to me!”
And, having opened his big register( 记录簿 ), the geographer sharpened( 削尖 ) his pencil.
The recitals( 叙述 ) of explorers are put down first in pencil.
One waits until the explorer has furnished( 提供 ) proofs( 证据 ), before putting them down in ink.
“Well?” said the geographer expectantly( 满怀期待地 ).
“Oh, where I live,” said the little prince,
“it is not very interesting. It is all so small. I have three volcanoes( 火山 ). Two volcanoes( 火山 ) are active and the other is extinct( 不再活跃的 ). But one never knows.”
“One never knows,” said the geographer.
“I also have a flower.”
“We do not record flowers,” said the geographer.
“Why is that? The flower is the most beautiful thing on my planet!”
“We do not record them,” said the geographer, “because they are ephemeral( 转瞬即逝的 ).”
“What does that mean—‘ephemeral( 转瞬即逝的 )’?”
“Geographies,” said the geographer, “are the books which, of all books, are most concerned with matters of consequence.
They never become old-fashioned( 过时的 ). It is very rarely that a mountain changes its position. It is very rarely that an ocean empties itself of its waters. We write of eternal( 永恒的 ) things.”
“But extinct volcanoes( 死火山 ) may come to life( 苏醒 ) again,” the little prince interrupted. “What does that mean—‘ephemeral( 转瞬即逝的 )’?”
“Whether volcanoes( 火山 ) are extinct( 不再活跃的 ) or alive, it comes to the same thing for us,” said the geographer. “The thing that matters to us is the mountain. It does not change.”
“But what does that mean—‘ephemeral( 转瞬即逝的 )’?” repeated the little prince, who never in his life had let go of a question, once he had asked it.
“It means, ‘which is in danger of speedy disappearance.’ ”
“Is my flower in danger of speedy disappearance?”
“Certainly it is.”
“My flower is ephemeral( 转瞬即逝的 ),” the little prince said to himself, “and she has only four thorns( 刺 ) to defend herself against the world. And I have left her on my planet, all alone!”
That was his first moment of regret. But he took courage once more.
“What place would you advise me to visit now?” he asked.
“The planet Earth,” replied the geographer. “It has a good reputation( 名声 ).”
And the little prince went away, thinking of his flower.
So then the seventh planet was the Earth.
The Earth is not just an ordinary planet!
One can count, there, 111 kings (not forgetting, to be sure, the Negro( 黑人 ) kings among them), 7,000 geographers, 900,000 businessmen, 7,500,000 tipplers( 酒鬼 ), 311,000,000 conceited( 自负的 ) men
—that is to say, about 2,000,000,000 grown-ups( 成年人 ).
To give you an idea of the size of the Earth, I will tell you that before the invention of electricity it was necessary to maintain( 维持 ),
over the whole of the six continents, a veritable( 名副其实的 ) army of 462,511 lamplighters( 点街灯的人 ) for the street lamps.
Seen from a slight distance, that would make a splendid spectacle( 壮观场面 ).
The movements of this army would be regulated( 被管理 ) like those of the ballet( 芭蕾舞团 ) in the opera.
First would come the turn of the lamplighters( 点街灯的人 ) of New Zealand and Australia.
Having set their lamps alight( 点亮的 ), these would go off to sleep.
Next, the lamplighters( 点街灯的人 ) of China and Siberia( 西伯利亚 ) would enter for their steps in the dance, and then they too would be waved back into the wings.
After that would come the turn of the lamplighters( 点街灯的人 ) of Russia and the Indies( 印度 ); then those of Africa and Europe, then those of South America; then those of North America.
And never would they make a mistake in the order of their entry upon the stage.
It would be magnificent( 宏伟的 ).
Only the man who was in charge of the single lamp at the North Pole( 北极 ), and his colleague( 同事 ) who was responsible for the single lamp at the South Pole( 南极 )
—only these two would live free from toil( 辛苦劳作 ) and care: they would be busy twice a year.
When one wishes to play the wit( 才智 ), he sometimes wanders a little from the truth.
I have not been altogether honest in what I have told you about the lamplighters( 点街灯的人 ).
And I realize that I run the risk of giving a false idea of our planet to those who do not know it.
Men occupy( 占据 ) a very small place upon the Earth.
If the two billion inhabitants( 居民 ) who people its surface were all to stand upright( 笔直地 ) and somewhat crowded together, as they do for some big public assembly( 集会 ),
they could easily be put into one public square twenty miles long and twenty miles wide.
All humanity could be piled up( 堆积 ) on a small Pacific islet( 小岛 ).
The grown-ups( 成年人 ), to be sure, will not believe you when you tell them that.
They imagine that they fill a great deal of space.
They fancy themselves as important as the baobabs( 猴面包树 ).
You should advise them, then, to make their own calculations.
They adore( 喜爱 ) figures, and that will please them.
But do not waste your time on this extra task.
It is unnecessary.
You have, I know, confidence in me.
When the little prince arrived on the Earth, he was very much surprised not to see any people.
He was beginning to be afraid he had come to the wrong planet, when a coil( 圈 ) of gold, the color of the moonlight, flashed across the sand.
“Good evening,” said the little prince courteously( 恭敬地 ).
“Good evening,” said the snake.
“What planet is this on which I have come down?” asked the little prince.
“This is the Earth; this is Africa,” the snake answered.
“Ah! Then there are no people on the Earth?”
“This is the desert. There are no people in the desert. The Earth is large,” said the snake.
The little prince sat down on a stone, and raised his eyes toward the sky.
“I wonder,” he said, “whether the stars are set alight( 点亮的 ) in heaven so that one day each one of us may find his own again . . .
Look at my planet. It is right there above us. But how far away it is!”
“It is beautiful,” the snake said. “What has brought you here?”
“I have been having some trouble with a flower,” said the little prince.
“Ah!” said the snake.
And they were both silent.
“Where are the men?” the little prince at last took up the conversation again. “It is a little lonely in the desert . . .”
“It is also lonely among men,” the snake said.
The little prince gazed( 注视 ) at him for a long time.
“You are a funny animal,” he said at last. “You are no thicker than a finger . . .”
“But I am more powerful than the finger of a king,” said the snake.
The little prince smiled.
“You are not very powerful. You haven’t even any feet. You cannot even travel . . .”
“I can carry you farther than any ship could take you,” said the snake. He twined( 使缠绕 ) himself around the little prince’s ankle( 脚踝 ), like a golden bracelet( 镯子 ).
“Whomever I touch, I send back to the earth from whence( 从那里 ) he came,” the snake spoke again. “But you are innocent and true, and you come from a star . . .”
The little prince made no reply.
“You move me to pity—you are so weak on this Earth made of granite( 花岗石 ),” the snake said. “I can help you, someday, if you grow too homesick( 想家的 ) for your own planet. I can—”
“Oh! I understand you very well,” said the little prince. “But why do you always speak in riddles( 谜语 )?”
“I solve them all,” said the snake.
And they were both silent.

article_info.previous: 小王子来到一个很小的行星，和一个点街灯的人做了朋友。随后，他又去了一个很大的行星，认识了一位地理学家。
article_info.share_words: “My flower is ephemeral,” the little prince said to himself, “and she has only four thorns to defend herself against the world. And I have left her on my planet, all alone!”

question.cn: 为什么地理学家不记录花朵？
question.en: Why did the geographer NOT record flowers?

options.en: Because there were too many of them.

analysis: 原文中：地理学家说：“We do not record them,” said the geographer, “because they are ephemeral.”所以答案为C。

question.cn: 小王子到了地球的什么地方？
question.en: Where did the little prince arrive in the Earth?

analysis: 原文中，小王子到达地球后，蛇告诉他：“This is the desert. There are no people in the desert. The Earth is large,” said the snake. 所以答案为C

question.en: What did the little prince think of the snake?

analysis: 原文提到：The little prince gazed at him for a long time.“You are a funny animal,” he said at last. “You are no thicker than a finger . . .” 所以答案为B。

share_title: 100天读完4本英文书，今天是第9天
